item.title: 10 Things That Never Happened
item.description: It’s about grief and melancholy and connection and hope; it hit me so hard in the feels I cried through the last chapters.

item.title: A Lady’s Guide to Fortune-Hunting
item.description: I didn’t love this quite as much as [[books/a lady’s guide to scandal|book two]]. (Read them out of order, oops!) Lots of promise, but I think the difference in POV—floating omniscient instead of tight third—didn’t work quite as well for me, possibly because it’s such a high bar of difficulty, possibly because it’s much closer to Jane Austen’s voice, which means the differences in quality are glaring.

item.title: Boyfriend Material
item.description: I’m doing a reading challenge for the local library and need “a book that became a movie” for bingo, and how I wish this book qualified because, if Hollywood knew what they were doing, it should be optioned and filmed before I finish this sentence.

item.title: Gideon the Ninth
item.description: WOULD HAVE HARROWHARK’S BABIES. I mean, it’s a good thing I like nice people in real life, because in fiction, Harrowhark is 10000% my type.

item.title: Inferno
item.description: So good to read this while steeped in Florentine history. These are real people and real places, not just an abstract Lewis-esque allegory.

item.title: Prosperity
item.description: Adore it truly, deeply.

item.title: Something Fabulous
item.description: So far the theme of the year is romances that I read and then re-read right away and install on my best-of-year list (best-of-ever list too, in the case of Something Fabulous, which more than lives up to its name).

item.title: The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi
item.description: A rollicking pirate adventure AND an extensive bibliography for the historical accuracies! Be still my heart! This was brilliant. It would be easier to make a list of the things I didn’t like about it than all the things I loved.

item.title: Harrow the Ninth
item.description: Amount of times this book made me cry: [redacted]. It is a sum equal to or only slightly less than the amount of times it made me cackle, gasp, and yelp.

item.title: A Lady’s Guide to Scandal
item.description: Aah, this was so fun! It righted some wrongs from Persuasion (I’m not a Wentworth fan, okay—don’t @ me), and threw in enough hijinks that it didn’t have to be a faithful retelling.

item.title: Husband Material
item.description: Choosing to interrogate the state of matrimony, I should have expected nothing less from Alexis Hall. I had to read this twice to really like it, because I am so urgggggh about weddings, and I needed the ending spoiled to get fully on board:

item.title: Liberty & Other Stories
item.description: I did not think I could love the [[series/prosperityverse|Prosperityverse]] more, BUT I DO.

item.title: Purgatorio
item.description: Reading this alongside Guido Ruggiero’s [[books/the renaissance in italy|The Renaissance in Italy]] is A+ recommended. Once again, vastly more interesting than my first exposure, where school curriculum wanted it read like it was Pilgrim’s Progress.

item.title: Nona the Ninth
item.description: Verdict still stands after book three: would have Harrowhark’s babies. The end of [[books/gideon the ninth|Gideon]] had some pacing things, the start of [[books/harrow the ninth|Harrow]] had some pacing things; Nona was the one I barreled through in 1.

item.title: Paradiso
item.description: My dilemma since the early years of Sunday school: hell is more interesting than paradise. Thus, true to form, though I wanted to be contrary, [[books/inferno|Inferno]] is more interesting than any amount of heavenly light (so bright!

item.title: The Price of Meat
item.description: Maybe don’t read this over lunch like I did? By which I mean, it’s fanfic of Sweeney Todd, it’s grisly horror, and it’s very good and effective, because KJ Charles.

item.title: Wanted, A Gentleman
item.description: She had me at “gothic novelist” and “lonely hearts columnist.” This is wonderful. I love it when Charles just unleashes her id.

item.title: William Blake: The Complete Illuminated Books
item.description: Reading Blake, I always get the sense he’s working in a fever, trying to translate an ecstatic vision for us mortals.

item.title: Emma of 83rd Street
item.description: Emma is my favorite Austen, and arguably the most difficult to modernize without losing the spirit of the story.1 I don’t envy any author who attempts it, but this one lost me in the weeds, with pacing that seems twice the length of Austen with half the page count.

item.title: Gwen & Art Are Not in Love
item.description: I think it wobbled a smiiiidge on the landing, a few things felt abrupt and/or undercooked, not to mention the jarring tonal shift into violence, but the ride to get there was super fun.

item.title: Infamous
item.description: This ending was the EXACT ENDING I’ve wanted to see for SO LONG. (Unapologetic all caps.) It took us ages to get there (more on that in a sec) but once we did?

item.title: Kiss Her Once for Me
item.description: Tried this one again, hoping I had one more festive read in me for the year, but there are just sooo many things that bug me right away.

item.title: On the Fox Roads
item.description: Nghi Vo can write [[books/the chosen and the beautiful|queer Jazz Age fanfic]] for me all day any day. (Also excellent: the Venn diagram of her Chinese and Vietnamese characters, the overlapping similarities and the differences.

item.title: Orlando Furioso
item.description: A note on translation: I used Reynolds to compare, contrast, and fill in the gaps with the [[books/orlando furioso a new verse translation|Slavitt translation]].

item.title: Orlando Furioso: A New Verse Translation
item.description: Ariosto writing like AO3 was a thing in the sixteenth century. I love it. Fiendishly clever layers of satire; a story where anything goes.

item.title: Racing to You
item.description: “Has someone written a romance about pro cycling?” was something I wondered last week. And voila, this book. It actually:

item.title: Reputation
item.description: Lex Croucher’s lols-per-page cannot be beat. Weirdly, the only character I was meh on was the love interest, just because he’s too perfect.

item.title: Starlings
item.description: My favorite stories are clustered right in the middle: “What A Piece of Work,” “Parable Lost,” “What Would Sam Spade Do?

item.title: The Black Jersey
item.description: It takes until page 280 for the main character to say, “I am an imbecile,” which is the truest thing in the book.

item.title: The Chosen and the Beautiful
item.description: As someone who has long loved [[authors/f scott fitzgerald|F. Scott Fitzgerald]]’s writing, despite his depressing and often problematic deal, this [[books/the great gatsby|Gatsby]] retelling vis-à-vis a Vietnamese Jordan Baker is exquisite.

item.title: The Dragon Waiting
item.description: “The Velvet Underground of novels,” as Scott Lynch says in the introduction. This book is a masterwork. If I ever mix up my history on the Medicis, the War of the Roses, and the Byzantine Empire, it’s probably because I’ve misremembered this fiction as fact.

item.title: The Spirit Ring
item.description: Sometimes when things connect, they really connect. I picked this up because I was ready for another Bujold, and this is what the library had, and what is right there when I open it up?

item.title: Thornhedge
item.description: Aaaah the greenteeth! Toadling! A knight to the rescue that I don’t want to punch in the throat! But the GREENTEETH!
